oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Combining food web theory and population dynamics to assess the impact of invasive species
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Vagnon, Chloé
Rohr, Rudolf P.
Bersier, Louis-Félix
Cattanéo, Franck
Guillard, Jean
Frossard, Victor
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: invasive species
invasion impact
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>The impacts of invasive species on resident communities are driven by a tangle of ecological interactions difficult to quantify empirically. Combining a niche model with a population dynamic model, both allometrically parametrized, may represent a consistent framework to investigate invasive species impacts on resident communities in a food web context when empirical data are scarce. We used this framework to assess the ecological consequences of an invasive apex predator (<jats:italic>Silurus glanis</jats:italic>) in peri-Alpine lake food webs. Both increases and decreases of resident species abundances were highlighted and differed when accounting for different <jats:italic>S. glanis</jats:italic> body sizes. Complementarily, the prominence of indirect effects, such as trophic cascades, suggested that common approaches may only capture a restricted fraction of invasion consequences through direct predation or competition. By leveraging widely available biodiversity data, our approach may provide relevant insights for a comprehensive assessment and management of invasive species impacts on aquatic ecosystems.</jats:p>
